{{Infobox congressman | name = John Cadwalader | image = JohnCadwaladerOld.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1805|04|01}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1879|01|26|1805|04|01}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] | death_place = Philadelphia, Pennsylvania | office1 = Judge of the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania]] | appointer1 = [[James Buchanan]] | term_start1 = April 24, 1858 | term_end1 = January 26, 1879 | predecessor1 = [[John K. Kane]] | successor1 = [[William Butler (judge)|William Butler]] | state2 = [[Pennsylvania]] | district2 = [[Pennsylvania's 5th congressional district|5th]] | term_start2 = March 4, 1855 | term_end2 = March 3, 1857 | predecessor2 = [[John McNair (congressman)|John McNair]] | successor2 = [[Owen Jones (congressman)|Owen Jones]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | alma_mater = [[University of Pennsylvania]] | parents = Mary Biddle
Thomas Cadwalader | spouse = {{marriage|Mary Binney
||1831|reason=her death}}
{{marriage|Henrietta Maria Bancker
||January 26, 1879|reason=his death}} | relations = [[Clement Biddle]] (grandfather)
[[John Cadwalader (general)|John Cadwalader]] (grandfather) }} '''John Cadwalader''' (April 1, 1805 – January 26, 1879) was an American lawyer, [[jurist]], and politician from [[Philadelphia]]. ==Early life== Cadwalader was born in [[Philadelphia]] on April 1, 1805. He was the son of Mary ([[née]] Biddle) Cadwalader (1781–1850), of the Philadelphia [[Biddle family]], and military leader Thomas Cadwalader (1779–1841). Among his siblings were brothers General [[George Cadwalader]], Thomas Cadwalader, Henry Cadwalader, and William Cadwalader. His paternal grandfather was General [[John Cadwalader (general)|John Cadwalader]] and his great-grandfather was Dr. [[Thomas Cadwalader]].{{cite web |title= All-in-One Tree of John Cadwalader, Brg. Gen. |publisher= [[Historical Society of Pennsylvania]] | work= Cadwalader collection |url= http://www.hsp.org/files/findingaid1454cadwaladerfamilytree.pdf |accessdate= March 11, 2011 }} His maternal grandfather, [[Clement Biddle]], was also a military leader, having served under [[George Washington]] during the [[American Revolution|Revolutionary War]]. Cadwalader received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1821, and [[read law]] in 1825. ==Career== From 1825 to 1855, Cadwalader was in private practice. He was a lawyer for the [[Second Bank of the United States|Bank of the United States]] in 1830, and was vice provost of the Law Academy of Philadelphia from 1833 to 1853. He was a captain of the [[Pennsylvania State Militia]] in [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]] in 1844, which was called out for the [[Philadelphia Nativist Riots]]. ===U.S. Congress=== He was elected as a [[Democratic Party of Pennsylvania|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]], representing Pennsylvania in the [[34th United States Congress]] from 1855 to 1857. He did not run for re-election.{{CongBio |C000011 |John Cadwalader |inline=please}} After completing his term in Congress, he resumed the practice of law in Philadelphia. ===Federal Judge=== Cadwalader was nominated by President [[James Buchanan]] on April 19, 1858, to be a federal judge on the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania]]. He replaced former [[Attorney General of Pennsylvania]] [[John K. Kane|John Kintzing Kane]], who died in office. He was confirmed by the [[United States Senate]] on April 24, 1858, and received his commission the same day,{{FJC Bio|346|nid=1378696|name=John Cadwalader}} serving during the entirety of the [[U.S. Civil War]] and until his death in 1879. After his death, he was succeeded by [[William Butler (judge)|William Butler]], who was nominated by President [[Rutherford B. Hayes]].{{cite web |title=Butler, William |url=https://www.fjc.gov/node/1378646 |website=www.fjc.gov |publisher=[[Federal Judicial Center]] |accessdate=21 June 2018 |language=en}} ==Personal life== [[File:John-Cadwalader.jpg|thumb|right|Portrait of the jurist's son, John Cadwalader Jr.]][[File:Mary Cadwalader Rawle.jpg|thumb|right|His granddaughter, Mary Cadwalader Rawle, painted by [[William Oliver Stone]] (1868)]] Cadwalader first married Mary Binney (1805–1831), daughter of [[Horace Binney]], an [[National Republican Party|Anti-Jacksonian]] [[U.S. Representative]] known for his public speeches; he founded the [[Hasty Pudding Club]] at [[Harvard]].{{cite web|title=Binney family papers 1809-1894|url=https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/clementsmss/umich-wcl-M-4362bin?view=text|website=quod.lib.umich.edu|publisher=[[University of Michigan|Manuscripts Division William L. Clements Library University of Michigan]]|accessdate=1 December 2017}} Together, Mary and John had two daughters:{{cite book |author1=Charles Penrose Keith |title=The provincial councillors of Pennsylvania, who held office between 1733–1776: and those earlier councillors who were some time chief magistrates of the province, and their descendants |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=OEAVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA382 |year=1883 |publisher=W.S. Sharp Printing Company |pages= 260, 381–382 }} * Mary Binney Cadwalader (1829–1861), who married lawyer William Henry Rawle (1823–1889), grandson of [[William Rawle]], in 1849.{{cite book |last1=Waite |first1=Morrison Remick |last2=Rawle |first2=William Henry |title=The Orations of Chief Justice Waite and of William Henry Rawle on the Occasion of the Unveiling of the Bronze Statue of Chief Justice Marshall at Washington, May 10, 1884 |date=1900 |publisher=T. H. Flood |pages=19-20 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vb46AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA19 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |language=en}} * Elizabeth Binney Cadwalader (born 1831), who married George Harrison Hare (1822–1857), the son of chemist Dr. [[Robert Hare (chemist)|Robert Hare]].{{cite book |last1=Jordan |first1=John W. |title=Colonial And Revolutionary Families Of Pennsylvania |date=2004 |publisher=Genealogical Publishing Com |isbn=9780806352398 |page=131 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arAfWBsvO1gC&pg=PA131 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |language=en}} Following his first wife's death from complications of childbirth, he married Henrietta Maria Bancker (1806–1889) with whom he had six children: * Sarah Bancker Cadwalader (born 1834). * Frances Cadwalader (1835–1881). * Thomas Cadwalader (1837–1841), who died young. * Charles Evert Cadwalader (1839–1907). * Anne Cadwalader (1841–1878). * John Cadwalader Jr. (1843–1925), who married Mary Helen Fisher (1844–1937).{{cite book |last1=Chamberlain |first1=Joshua Lawrence |title=University of Pennsylvania: Its History, Influence, Equipment and Characteristics; with Biographical Sketches and Portraits of Founders, Benefactors, Officers and Alumni |date=1902 |publisher=R. Herndon Company |page=117 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xIhPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA117 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |language=en}}{{cite book |title=Who's Who in Finance, Banking, and Insurance |date=1922 |publisher=Who's Who in Finance, Incorporated (N.Y.) |pages=110-111 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9aooAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA110 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |language=en}} * George Cadwalader (1845–1846), who died young.{{cite web |title= John Cadwalader Descent to Thomas F. Cadwalader II |work= Cadwalader Family Genealogy web site |url= http://cadwalader.net/johncadwaladerdescent.html |accessdate= March 11, 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101120140751/http://cadwalader.net/johncadwaladerdescent.html |archivedate= November 20, 2010 |df= }} Cadwalader died on January 26, 1879.{{cite news |title= Death of Judge Cadwalader: The Career of a Remarkable Jurist Ended |newspaper= [[New York Times]] | url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1879/01/27/80744477.pdf |format=PDF |date= January 27, 1879 }} He was buried in the [[Christ Church Burial Ground]] at the old [[Christ Church (Philadelphia)|Christ Church]] in Philadelphia. ===Descendants=== Through his eldest daughter Mary, he was the grandfather of [[Mary Cadwalader Rawle Jones|Mary Cadwalader Rawle]] (1850–1935), who was married on March 24, 1870 to Frederick Rhinelander Jones, the brother of [[Edith Wharton]]; their daughter in turn was landscape architect [[Beatrix Farrand|Beatrix Cadwalader Jones Farrand]] (1872–1959). Mary was prominent in New York society during the [[Gilded Age]]. She was included in [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families, published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=5 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}} Conveniently, 400 was the number of people that could fit into Mrs. Astor's ballroom.{{cite book|last1=Keister|first1=Lisa A.|title=Getting Rich: America's New Rich and How They Got That Way|date=2005|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=9780521536677|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dAtJf1hmAUC&pg=PA36|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Homberger|first1=Eric|title=Mrs. Astor's New York: Money and Social Power in a Gilded Age|date=2004|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|isbn=0300105150|pages=199, 289n.99|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=13jwkUPvYGcC&pg=PA329|accessdate=6 March 2018|language=en}} His grandson, John Cadwalader III (1874–1934), became trustee of the estate of his aunt Sophia Georgiana (née Fisher) Coxe (1841–1926) which funded the [[MMI Preparatory School]].{{cite web |title= John Cadwalader, III Collection |year= 2007 |publisher= [[Historical Society of Pennsylvania]] | work= Collection 3014 |url= http://www.hsp.org/files/findingaid3014cadwalader.pdf |accessdate= March 11, 2011 }} {{Cadwalader family tree}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * The [http://www.hsp.org/files/findingaid1454cadwaladerpart1.pdf Cadwalader Family Papers], documenting the Cadwalader family through four generations in America, are available for research use at the [[Historical Society of Pennsylvania]]. * {{Find a Grave |11462574 |John Cadwalader}} {{CongBio|C000011}} * {{cite web |title= Mary Cadwalader "Minnie" Rawle |work= Geer Family Master File |publisher= Rootsweb |url= http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=geer_family_tree&id=I589373 |accessdate= March 11, 2011 }} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state = Pennsylvania | district = 5 | before = [[John McNair (congressman)|John McNair]] | after = [[Owen Jones (congressman)|Owen Jones]] | years = March 4, 1855 – March 3, 1857 }} {{s-legal}} {{for|his son|Julio Mario Santo Domingo, Jr.}} {{Infobox ambassador |name = Julio Mario Santo Domingo Pumarejo |image = |imagesize = |alt = |order = 1st |ambassador_from = Colombia |country = China |term_start = 27 February 1981 |term_end = 18 March 1983 |predecessor = ''Office created'' |successor = [[Alfonso Gómez Gómez]] |president = [[Julio César Turbay Ayala]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|10|16|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Panama City]], [[Panamá Province|Panamá]], [[Panama]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|10|07|1923|10|16|df=yes}} |death_place = New York City, United States |nationality = [[Colombian people|Colombian]] |party = |spouse = Edyala Braga Brandão do Monte (-)
Beatrice Dávila Rocha (1975–2011) |children = [[Julio Mario Santo Domingo Braga]]
[[Alejandro Santo Domingo Dávila]]
Andrés Santo Domingo Dávila |relatives = [[Tatiana Santo Domingo Rechulski]] (granddaughter) |alma_mater = [[University of Virginia]] (, ) |occupation = |profession = |religion = [[Roman Catholic]] |signature = |signature_alt = |blank1 = Net worth |data1 = {{Gain}} US$8.4 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (2011){{cite journal |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/julio-mario-santo-domingo/ |title=Julio Mario Santo Domingo |journal=[[Forbes]]; The World's Billionaires |accessdate=2011-10-24 |date=March 2011}} }} {{Spanish name|Santo Domingo|Pumarejo}} '''Julio Mario Santo Domingo Pumarejo''' (October 16, 1923 – October 7, 2011){{cite web|url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/empresas/jugada/poquer/elpnegemp/20050904elpnegemp_6/Tes |title=Una jugada de póquer |author= D. A. Crowe|work=[[El País]]|date=2005-09-04}} was a [[Colombia]]n [[businessman]], diplomat and patriarch of the wealthy Santo Domingo family. He controlled more than 100 companies in the diversified portfolio of the "Santo Domingo Group." He was listed by ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine as one of the wealthiest men in the world, and the second-wealthiest in Colombia, with a fortune of $8 billion [[United States dollar|U.S. dollars]].{{cite web|url= https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/10/billionaires08_Julio-Mario-Santo-Domingo_YNZG.html |author= |work=[[Forbes]]|date=2008-03-05 |title=Billionaires: Julio Mario Santo Domingo}} He was the founder of a philanthropic foundation, named to honor his father, that benefits Colombia's social development. ==Early life== Julio Mario Santo Domingo was born on 16 October 1923 in [[Panama City]], [[Panama]], to Julio Mario Santo Domingo Santo Domingo and Beatriz Pumarejo de Vengoechea, the youngest of their four children; his older siblings were Beatriz Alicia, Cecilia, and Luis Felipe. His father was a banker, described as austere and disciplined, who made a fortune buying companies weakened during the [[Great Depression]]; his mother, from a rich and influential family, was [[first cousin]] of [[Alfonso López Pumarejo]] who was twice [[President of Colombia]]. He grew up in [[Barranquilla]] and later attended the exclusive [[Gimnasio Moderno]] in [[Bogotá, D.C.]], ultimately culminating his [[Secondary education|secondary studies]] at the [[Phillips Academy]] in [[Andover, Massachusetts]]; he later attended [[University of Virginia]] before transferring to [[Georgetown University]], but did not finish his degree. ==Ambassadorship== On 26 May 1980, [[President of Colombia|President]] [[Julio César Turbay Ayala]] appointed Santo Domingo to be the first [[Ambassador of Colombia to China]]. He presented his [[Letters of Credence]] to [[Ulanhu]], Vice Chairman of the [[Standing Committee of the National People's Congress]], in [[Beijing]] on 17 February 1981.{{cite news |title=Summary of world broadcasts: Far East, Part 3 |author=[[BBC Asian Network]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n2HVAAAAMAAJ |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |newspaper= |publisher=[[BBC Monitoring]] |location=[[Caversham Park]] |issn= |oclc=10807079 |date=1981-02-27 |page= |pages= |at= |accessdate=2011-10-24}} ==Santo Domingo Group== The Group has a majority stake in [[Bavaria Brewery (Colombia)|Bavaria Brewery]] and Valores Bavaria (a holding company for his non-beer interests). In 2005, Bavaria Brewery merged with South African company [[SABMiller]]. In this merging, the group acquired 15.1% of SAB Miller, becoming the second-largest shareholder of the second-largest beer company in the world (behind [[Anheuser-Busch InBev]]).{{cite web|url= http://www.sabmiller.com/sabmiller.com/en_gb/News+and+media/News+releases/Group+news/SABMiller+and+Bavaria+announce+a+major+transaction+in+Latin+America.htm |title= SABMiller and Bavaria announce a major transaction in Latin America |last= Timmons|first=Heather |work=[[International Herald Tribune]]|date=2005-07-19}}{{cite web|url= http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/07/18/business/beer.php |title=SABMiller buys brewer to grow in Latin America |author= |publisher=SAB Miller|date=2005-07-19}} ===Portfolio=== * [[Caracol TV]] (Colombian television channel) ** [[Caracol TV International]] ** [[Caracol Radio]] (sold to [[PRISA]] in 2001) * ''[[Revista Cromos|Cromos]]'' (magazine) * ''[[El Espectador]]'' (newspaper) * [[SABMiller]] (14% stake) * [[Avianca]] (sold in 2004 to [[Germán Efromovich]])[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/10/YNZG.html Forbes Billionaires, 2006] * [[Bluradio]] (radio station) ==Personal life== He first married to Edyala Braga Brandão do Monte, a Brazilian socialite, daughter of Brazilian ambassador in Paris and former wife of Brazilian President [[Getúlio Vargas]]' brother. Together they had one son, [[Julio Mario Santo Domingo Braga]] (1958–2009){{cite web|url= http://www.laht.com/article.asp?ArticleId=330732&CategoryId=12393 |title=Colombian Businessman Julio Mario Santo Domingo Braga Dies |author= |publisher=[[Latin American Herald Tribune]]|date=2009-03-29}}, but the marriage did not last long and they divorced shortly after. Julio Mario Jr. married Vera Rechulski, a Brazilian socialite and they had 2 children - [[Tatiana Santo Domingo]] (born November 24, 1983) and Julio Mario Santo Domingo III (born May 2, 1985). He remarried on 15 February 1975 to Colombian socialite Beatrice Dávila Rocha, and together they had two sons, [[Alejandro Santo Domingo Dávila]] (b. 1977) who has continued on in the family business and Andrés Santo Domingo Dávila (b. 1978) the co-founder and president of [[Kemado Records]], who in 2008 married socialite [[Lauren Santo Domingo|Lauren Davis]] (then founder of the online fashion retailer [[Moda Operandi]]). Santo Domingo owned homes in New York City, in Paris, and Barú, a Colombian island near Cartagena. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last1=Reyes |first1=Gerardo |title=Don Julio Mario: biografía no autorizada del hombre más poderoso de Colombia |trans-title=Don Julio Mario: non authorized biography of the most powerful man of Colombia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LEhsAAAAMAAJ |series=Crónica actual |format=Biography |year=2003 |publisher=Ediciones B |location=Barcelona |language=Spanish |isbn=978-958-96022-8-7 |oclc=150360666}} ==External links== {{wikinews|SABMiller acquires Colombian Grupo Bavaria brewery}} * [https://www.forbes.com/finance/lists/10/2004/LIR.jhtml?passListId=10&passYear=2004&passListType=Person&uniqueId=YNZG&datatype=Person Forbes.com: Forbes: World's Richest People] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091002013653/http://www.latinbusinesschronicle.com/app/article.aspx?id=3252 Latin Business Chronicle: Latin America's Billionaires] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141227181415/http://www.caracoltv.com/julio-mario-santo-domingo-pumarejo/video-243176-julio-mario-santo-domingo-1923-2011 The Death of Julio Mario Santo Domingo] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111015104255/http://www.caracoltv.com/julio-mario-santo-domingo-pumarejo Caracol Televisión special coverage on Julio Mario Santo Domingo] * [http://www.elespectador.com/opinion/editorial/articulo-304363-don-julio-mario-santo-domingo-p-1923-2011 Julio Mario Santo Domingo P. (1923–2011)] * [https://archive.is/20130118172521/http://caracoltv.com/julio-mario-santo-domingo-pumarejo/galeria-243164-julio-mario-santo-domingo-imagenes Julio Mario Santo Domingo on images] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Santo Domingo Pumarejo, Julio Mario}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:People from Panama City]] [[Category:Santo Domingo family|Julio Mario]] [[Category:Panamanian people of Colombian descent]] [[Category:Colombian people of Panamanian descent]] [[Category:Colombian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:University of Virginia alumni]] [[Category:Colombian billionaires]] [[Category:Colombian businesspeople]] [[Category:Colombian chief executives]] [[Category:Colombian philanthropists]] [[Category:Businesspeople in brewing]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Colombia to China]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Boyaca]] [[Category:20th-century businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century businesspeople]]

{{Infobox company | name = Lam Eng Rubber | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 1940 | location = [[Malaysia]] | industry = [[Rubber]] | products = [[Natural rubber]] [[latex]], [[Skim Block]], [[Standard Malaysian Rubber]] }} '''Lam Eng Rubber Factory (M) Sdn. Bhd.''' is a [[Malaysia]]n manufacturer of natural rubber.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nghospital.in/11/24_22348/Rubber_Processing_And_Equipment_Manufacturer_In_Malaysia/|title=Rubber Processing And Equipment Manufacturer In Malaysia|website=www.nghospital.in|language=en|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
The principal activities of the Company consist of processing and manufacturing of rubber and transportation services.
The Company's principal products, [[natural rubber]] [[latex]], [[skim block]] and [[Standard Malaysian Rubber]] are manufactured at their main factory in [[Sungai Petani]], [[Kedah]].
Lam Eng is a member of the [[Malaysian Rubber Board]] (Lembaga Getah Malaysia) and the International Rubber Association.
The company supplies [[natural rubber]] [[latex]] to [[Coco Industry]], [[Top Glove]], [[Supermax (Malaysia)]], etc.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{short description|Street in Jacksonville}} {{about|the street in Jacksonville}} {{Infobox street | name = Laura Street | marker_image = [[File:Laurastreet.png|120px]] | image = Jacksonvillebank.JPG | caption = View from the [[Bank of America Tower (Jacksonville)|Bank of America Tower]] looking toward [[Hemming Park]] | alternate_name = | owner = [[City of Jacksonville]] | maint = Department of Public Works | length_mi = | direction_a = North | terminus_a = 12th Street in [[Springfield (Jacksonville)|Springfield]] (contiguous segment) | direction_b = South | terminus_b = Independent Drive in [[Northbank (Jacksonville)|Northbank]] | arrondissement = | quarter = | postal_code = 32202, 32206 | metro = '''Monorail''':
[[Hemming Plaza (JTA Skyway)|Hemming Plaza Station]]
[[Rosa Parks Transit Station]] | junction = }} '''Laura Street''' is a north-south street in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], United States, named for the daughter of the city's founder, [[Isaiah D. Hart]]. Historically, the [[Downtown Jacksonville|downtown]] portion of Laura Street has been considered the [[financial district]] of Jacksonville. == Description == The street's contiguous segment runs from 12th Street in the historic neighborhood of [[Springfield (Jacksonville)|Springfield]] south through downtown, terminating at Independent Drive. South of State Street, Laura Street runs though the core of downtown's [[Downtown Jacksonville#Downtown Core|Northbank]], and is one of the busiest pedestrian streets in the city. Serving as an important corridor connecting a high concentration of office blocks, the area has historically functioned as a preeminent shopping and financial district, and has remained an important economic and cultural epicenter for the region. The street is also home to Jacksonville's oldest park, [[Hemming Park]], the [[Jacksonville Landing]], [[Jacksonville Public Library|Main Public Library]], the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville]], and [[St. James Building|City Hall]].{{cite web |last1=Bull |first1=Roger |title=Jacksonville's Laura Street named one of the top-5 streets in the nation |url=http://jacksonville.com/business/2015-09-30/story/jacksonvilles-laura-street-named-one-top-5-streets-nation |website=''Jacksonville.com'' |publisher=Florida Times-Union |accessdate=January 16, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161216181954/http://jacksonville.com/business/2015-09-30/story/jacksonvilles-laura-street-named-one-top-5-streets-nation |archivedate=December 16, 2016 |df=}} == History == Laura Street was named for the daughter of Jacksonville's founder, [[Isaiah D. Hart]].{{cite web |url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/030200/ent_S0302FIR.html |title=City had humble beginnings on the banks of the St. Johns |author=Judy Wells |date=March 2, 2000 |publisher=Florida Times-Union |accessdate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009090448/http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/030200/ent_S0302FIR.html#.WI0XTzYiy00 |archivedate=October 9, 2012 |df=}} In 1856, the city's oldest public park was designated along Laura Street, occupying the entire city block bordered by Monroe, Hogan and Duval Streets. The area attracted numerous hotels, most notably the St. James Hotel, completed in 1869, and the Windsor Hotel, completed in 1875.{{cite web |url=http://apps2.coj.net/parksinternet/parkdetails.asp?parkid=397 |title=Hemming Plaza |work=Park Details |publisher=City of Jacksonville |accessdate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303214056/http://apps2.coj.net/parksinternet/parkdetails.asp?parkid=397 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=}} [[File:LauraStreet1894.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Laura Street in 1894]] The [[Great Fire of 1901]] ravaged almost the entirety of today's modern downtown core, including much of Laura Street. The street did act as a fire line between the junctions of Adams Street through to the St. Johns River.{{cite web |url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2007-jan-distinguish-jacksonville-the-great-fire-of-1901 |title=Distinguish Jacksonville: The Great Fire of 1901 |date=January 6, 2007 |publisher=Metro Jacksonville |accessdate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929044827/http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2007-jan-distinguish-jacksonville-the-great-fire-of-1901 |archivedate=September 29, 2017 |df=}} Just as in the 1871 Great Chicago Fire, the massive level of destruction left in the wake of the fire precipitated a robust period growth and a building boom that would last up until the [[Great Depression]]. The corridor between Adams Street, where a remaining portion of the business district still existed, and Hemming Park, was the center of much of the more notable commercial development. [[File:Jaxfinpost.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Postcard depicting the Financial Center of Jacksonville, c.1910]] Originally the Mercantile Exchange Bank Building, one of the first buildings to be built after the fire was the [[Laura Street Trio#Old Florida National Bank|Old Florida National Bank]] in 1902. It was designed by Edward H. Glidden in the [[Classical Revival architecture|Classical Revival]] style, and is now part of a group of buildings known as the [[Laura Street Trio]]. Architect [[Henry John Klutho]] designed the other two buildings: the [[Bisbee Building]] in 1908, and the [[Florida Life Building]] in 1911, both designed in the [[Chicago school architecture|Chicago school]] of architecture. He also designed the YMCA Building in 1909, and the [[St. James Building]] in 1912.{{cite web |url=http://www.prairieschooltraveler.com/html/fl/lost/Lost-Treasures.html |title=Jacksonville's Lost Treasures |author=Wayne W. Wood |publisher=Prairie School Traveler |accessdate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525200928/http://www.prairieschooltraveler.com/html/fl/lost/Lost-Treasures.html |archivedate=May 25, 2017 |df=}} New York architecture firm [[Mowbray and Uffinger]] contributed two significant structures to the corridor during this period. In 1909, [[121 Atlantic Place]], originally Atlantic National Bank Building, opened as the tallest building in Florida. [[Barnett National Bank Building]] opened its doors in 1926, also breaking the state height record.{{cite web |url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2008-mar-a-century-of-floridas-tallest-skyscrapers |title=A Century of Florida's Tallest Skyscrapers |author=Ennis Davis |date=March 6, 2008 |publisher=Metro Jacksonville |accessdate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525200929/http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2008-mar-a-century-of-floridas-tallest-skyscrapers |archivedate=May 25, 2017 |df=}} Local architecture firm [[Marsh & Saxelbye]] also contributed multiple works along the route, including [[Karpeles Manuscript Library Museum (Jacksonville)|Karpeles Manuscript Library Museum]] (1921), [[Schultz Building]] (1926), [[Hotel George Washington (Jacksonville, Florida)|Hotel George Washington]] (1926) and [[Greenleaf & Crosby Building]] (1928). [[RTKL Associates Inc.]], a planning and consultant firm from [[Baltimore]], was hired in 1970 to study the city's increasing [[urban blight]] related to suburbanization and the development of retail malls. The recommendations were included in the 1971 Downtown Master Plan drafted by the Downtown Development Authority. The plans called for creating a [[pedestrian mall]], a one-way transportation loop and elevated walkways that would permitting safe movement from the retail core, centered on Hemming Park, to the riverfront. The plans further called for a riverfront park, convention center with attached hotel, an exhibition center, Sears Department Store, and a high-rise offices. Though many portions of the plan never came to fruition, a few of Laura Street's features are a result of the 1971 Downtown Master Plan, the most striking of which was the [[Wells Fargo Center (Jacksonville)|Wells Fargo Center]], designed by [[KBJ Architects|Kemp, Bunch & Jackson]] in 1974 for the Independent Life Insurance Company.{{cite web |url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2009-sep-visions-of-yesteryear-the-1971-downtown-master-plan |title=Visions of Yesteryear: The 1971 Downtown Master Plan |date=September 11, 2009 |publisher=Metro Jacksonville |accessdate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202044258/http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2009-sep-visions-of-yesteryear-the-1971-downtown-master-plan |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df=}} In 2011, $2.3 million was spent to enhance the street by adding traffic calming features, more sidewalk space, trees with colorful uplighting and other hardscape features. In 2015, a five-block segment of Laura Street beginning at West Duval Street near [[Hemming Park]], stretching to the [[Jacksonville Landing]], and ending at East Independent Drive, was recognized by the [[American Planning Association]] as one of its "Great Places in America."{{cite web |title=Great Places in America – Laura Street:Jacksonville, Florida |url=https://www.planning.org/greatplaces/streets/2015/laurastreet.htm |website=''Planning.org'' |publisher=American Planning Association |accessdate=January 16, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118063514/https://www.planning.org/greatplaces/streets/2015/laurastreet.htm |archivedate=January 18, 2017 |df=}} == Notable places == [[File:Suntrusttower.JPG|thumb|right|SunTrust Tower]] From south to north: * [[Jacksonville Landing]] and Andrew Jackson Statue, Independent Drive * [[SunTrust Tower]], Independent Drive * [[Wells Fargo Center (Jacksonville)|Wells Fargo Center]], between Independent Drive and Bay Street * [[Bank of America Tower (Jacksonville)|Bank of America Tower]], between Bay and Forsyth Streets * [[Jacksonville Bancorp|CenterState Bank Building]], Forsyth Street * [[121 Atlantic Place]], Forsyth Street * [[Laura Street Trio]], Forsyth Street * [[Barnett National Bank Building]], Adams Street * [[Greenleaf & Crosby Building]] and Jacobs Jewelers Clock, Adams Street * [[Elks Club Building (Jacksonville)|Elks Club Building]], Adams Street * [[The Carling]], Adams Street * [[Schultz Building]], Adams Street * [[Snyder Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church]], Monroe Street * Main branch of the [[Jacksonville Public Library]], Monroe Street * [[Hemming Park]], between Monroe and Duval Streets * [[Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville]], Duval Street * [[St. James Building|City Hall]] (St. James Building), between Duval and Church Streets * [[Florida State College at Jacksonville]] downtown campus, between State and 1st Streets * [[Karpeles Manuscript Library Museum (Jacksonville)|Karpeles Manuscript Library Museum]], 1st Street * [[Henry J. Klutho Park|Klutho Park]], 1st Street == Transportation == The Jacksonville Landing is at the southern terminus of Laura Street and offers access to the [[Jacksonville Water Taxi]] as well as other marine services. The [[Jacksonville Skyway]] serves two stations near Laura Street: * [[Hemming Park station]] at Monroe Street * [[Rosa Parks Transit Station]] at State Street (central [[Jacksonville Transportation Authority|JTA]] bus station) == Gallery == File:The Jacksonville Landing, Jacksonville FL, Southeast view 20160706 1.jpg|Jacksonville Landing and Riverwalk on the St. Johns River File:OneECenterW.jpg|Statue of Andrew Jackson at the terminus of Laura Street at Independent Drive File:MLKDayWFC.jpg|Wells Fargo Center File:LaurabayWFC.jpg|Corner of Laura and Bay Streets File:LaurastBOAT.jpg|Laura Street entrance of the Bank of America Tower File:Hemming Plaza.JPG|Intersection of Laura and Forsyth Streets File:LauraStreetFinancialDistrict.jpg|thumb|Postcard depicting the Financial District of Jacksonville LauraStreetTrio20s.jpg|Laura Street Trio in the 1920s File:Jacobs Jewelers Street Clock, Jacksonville.JPG|Jacobs Jewelers Clock at the corner of Adams Street File:DTJax.jpg|View of the Northbank core from the Federal Courthouse File:MOCAFEDJax.jpg|Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville == See also == {{Portal bar|Business and economics|Florida|Jacksonville}} * [[Economy of Jacksonville]] * [[Architecture of Jacksonville]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Duval County, Florida]] == References == {{reflist|31em}} {{Authority control}} {{Coord|display=title|30.32732|-81.65922}} {{City of Jacksonville}} {{Florida}} {{Jacksonville attractions}} [[Category:Laura Street| ]] [[Category:Northbank, Jacksonville]] [[Category:Downtown Jacksonville]] [[Category:Economy of Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Economy of Florida]] [[Category:Financial districts in the United States]] [[Category:Shopping districts and streets in the United States]]

[[Image:Leon Van der Rest.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Leon Van der Rest]] '''Léon Van der Rest''' (1846–1932) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] lawyer, businessman and governor of the [[National Bank of Belgium]] (NBB) from 1918 until 1923.
==Career== He started his career as a lawyer at the Brussels Bar, but after a few years took charge of the family business as an [[ironmonger]]. Besides being active in the family business, he also served as commissioner for a number of other companies. In 1888 he became a member of the discount committee of the NBB, while being an administrator of the ''Crédit Anversois''. In 1898 he was appointed as a censor of the bank and in 1905 as a director. In 1912, he became vice-governor under [[Théophile de Lantsheere]]. When Théophile de Lantsheere was removed as governor of the bank by the Germans on 22 December 1914 at the start of the occupation of Belgium during [[World War I]], he became in charge of the NBB.
During the war Léon Van der Rest, was vice-president of the [[BAEF|National Aid and Food Provision Committee]], under [[Emile Francqui]]. After the war, he became governor of the NBB in 1918. The immediate postwar period knew a rampant inflation and loss of value of the [[belgian franc]]. In 1923, he did not seek the renewal of this term as governor and became the first honorary governor of the NBB. He was succeeded by [[Fernand Hautain]].
==Sources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110521063605/http://www.nbb.be/pub/01_00_00_00_00/01_02_00_00_00/01_02_02_00_00/01_02_02_08_01.htm?l=en&t=bu Léon Van der Rest]
{{s-start}} {{succession box | | before = [[Théophile de Lantsheere]] | after = [[Fernand Hautain]] | title = [[National Bank of Belgium|Governor of the National Bank of Belgium]] | years = 1918-1923 |}} {{s-end}} {{use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Van Der Rest, Leon}} [[Category:1846 births]] [[Category:1932 deaths]] [[Category:Belgian lawyers]] [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] [[Category:Belgian civil servants]] [[Category:Governors of the National Bank of Belgium]]
{{Belgium-business-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}}
'''Max Henri Boisot''' (11 November 1943 – 7 September 2011)<ref>http://www.internationalfuturesforum.com/s/remembering-max-boisot</ref><ref>http://cognitive-edge.com/blog/max-boisot-1943-2011/</ref> was a British architect and management consultant who was professor of Strategic Management at the [[ESADE]] business school in [[Barcelona]].<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.esade.edu/research/eng/graco/whoweare/esademembers|title= ESADE – GRACO Who we are > Esade members|accessdate=9 July 2010}}</ref> known for his ideas about the [[information economy]],<ref>Kurtz, Cynthia F., and David J. Snowden. "The new dynamics of strategy: Sense-making in a complex and complicated world." IBM systems journal 42.3 (2003): 462-483.</ref> the [[I-Space (conceptual framework)|Information Space]],<ref>Nahapiet, Janine, and [[Sumantra Ghoshal]]. "Social capital, intellectual capital, and the organizational advantage." Academy of management review 23.2 (1998): 242-266.</ref> [[social capital]] and [[social learning theory]].
== Biography == Boisot was born in [[Maidenhead]], [[Berkshire]], England, the son of Marcel Boisot and Hélène Cordet. He attended [[Gordonstoun]] boarding school in [[Moray]], Scotland, and later studied architecture at the [[University of Cambridge]] and city planning at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], before taking his PhD in technology transfer at [[Imperial College London]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Max Henri Boisot - Curriculum Vitae|url=http://www.uoc.edu/in3/esp/investigadors/Maxweb/mybio.html}}</ref>
After working as a manager for construction firm Trafalgar House, in 1972 Boisot co-founded an architectural partnership, Boisot Waters Cohen, and from 1975 to 1978 acted as a consultant on projects in France and the Middle East.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Fifty key figures in management|chapter=Max Boisot|author=Morgen Witzel|year=2003|publisher=Routledge}}</ref> from 1983 to 1989, he was Director and Dean of China Europe Management Institute in Beijing China.
Afterwards Boisot was Professor of Strategic Management at the [[ESADE]] business school in [[Barcelona]]. Associate Fellow at [[Templeton College]], [[University of Oxford]], and Senior Associate at the [[Cambridge Judge Business School|Judge Institute of Management Studies]] at the [[University of Cambridge]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jbs.cam.ac.uk/research/centres/cibam/people.html#academic|title=People – CIBAM – Faculty & Research – Cambridge Judge Business School|accessdate=9 July 2010}}</ref> He was also a research fellow at the Sol Snider Center, the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]].
His book ''Knowledge Assets'' was awarded the Ansoff Prize for the best book on strategy in 2000. The [[I-Space (conceptual framework)|I-Space framework]], which is central to his work, is an acknowledged early influence on the development of the [[Cynefin]] framework.<ref>Snowden, D. (2002) “Complex Acts of Knowing: Paradox and Descriptive Self Awareness” in the Journal of Knowledge Management – Vol. 6, No. 2 (May), pp. 100–111</ref> Boisot was a co-founder of the I-Space Institute, a research and consulting company that grew out of and is based on his work on the strategic management of knowledge.<ref>[http://www.ispaceinstitute.com About I-Space Institute]</ref>
Max Boisot died from cancer on 7 September 2011, aged 67.<ref>[http://www.cognitive-edge.com/blogs/dave/2011/09/max_boisot_19432011.php#more Max Boisot 1943-2011]</ref>
== Selected publications == * ''Information and Organization: The Manager as Anthropologist''. London: Collins (1987) * (Editor) ''East-West Collaboration: the Challenge of Governance in Post-Socialist Enterprises'', London: Routledge (1993) * ''Information Space: A Framework for Learning in Organizations Institutions and Cultures'', London: Routledge (1995) * ''Knowledge Assets: Securing Competitive Advantage in the Information Economy'', Oxford: Oxford University Press (1998). {{ISBN|978-0-19-829607-2}} * ''Explorations in Information Space: Knowledge, Agents and Organization'', co-authored with Ian C. MacMillan and Kyeong Seok Han, Oxford: Oxford University Press, (2007). {{ISBN|978-0-19-925087-5}} * ''Knowledge, Organization, and Management: Building on the Work of Max Boisot'', Edited by John Child and Martin Ihrig, Oxford: Oxford University Press, (2013). {{ISBN|978-0199669165}}
== EGOS Annual Award in Honour of Max Boisot == The EGOS Annual Award in Honour of Max Boisot recognizes an outstanding paper, with preference given to early career scholars.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://egosnet.org/jart/prj3/egos/main.jart?rel=de&content-id=1474852819754&reserve-mode=active|title= EGOS Annual Award in Honour of Max Boisot|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref> The topic for this award is the knowledge-based study of complex organizations and systems. Contributions in any of the main areas in which Max Boisot forged new understanding through a knowledge perspective are eligible for the award, in particular, research on organizational complexity; the strategic management of knowledge; China's business system; and Big Science.
Scientists who received this award include: * 2014 Liselore A. Havermans (VU University Amsterdam, NL), Deanne N. Den Hartog (University of Amsterdam, NL), and Anne Keegan (University of Amsterdam, NL). * 2015 Goran Calic, Sebastien Hélie, and Elaine Mosakowski (Purdue, University). * 2016 Tomas Farchi (IAE Business School, Buenos Aires, Argentina), Sue Dopson (University of Oxford, UK) & George Chondrakis (Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona, Spain) The Role of Hybrid Governing in Science: Fostering Research across Boundaries. * 2017 Jochem T. Hummel, Hans Berends & Philipp Tuertscher(VU University Amsterdam, Netherlands) What Do We Have in Common? Collective Action among Heterogeneous Actors in a Meta-organization.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * Leong, Lam Chuan. "[http://www.cscollege.gov.sg/Knowledge/Ethos/Ethos%20July%202005/Pages/Complexity,%20Bureaucracy%20and%20the%20Information%20Space.aspx Complexity, Bureaucracy and the Information Space]". Ethos (Jul–Sep 2005). * Savory, Clive (2006). "[http://oro.open.ac.uk/7094/ Translating knowledge to build technological competence]". Management Decision 44 (8): 1052–1075.
==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.internationalfuturesforum.com/s/remembering-max-boisot Remembering Max Boisot, 1943 - 2011] * [http://www.uoc.edu/in3/esp/investigadors/Maxweb/ Max Boisot] at Strategic Learning Partners
{{Authority control}}

'''Mecc Alte''' is an Italian electrical engineering company that makes [[Electric generator|electrical generator]]s. It is based in [[Vicenza]], in the [[Veneto]] region of north-east Italy.
==History== It was founded in 1947 in Alte near Vincenza.
==Products== The types of [[Permanent magnet synchronous generator|synchronous alternator]]s it makes are: * 2 pole (1 - 208 [[Volt-ampere|kVA]]) * 4 pole (3.5 - 3000 kVA) * 6 pole (500 - 2100 kVA)
It also makes * Permanent magnets * [[Welding power supply|Welding generator]]s
==See also == {{Portal|Italy|Companies}} *[[List of Italian companies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
